designScenario.name: Flap System
designScenario.description: The Flap System is a critical subsystem of the Flight Surfaces, responsible for modulating lift and drag during takeoff, landing, and high-lift maneuvers. It consists of deployable surfaces on the wings that extend or retract to alter aerodynamic profiles. The system ensures optimal lift-to-drag ratios, enhances low-speed stability, and reduces stall speeds. Designed for high reliability, it integrates redundant actuation mechanisms, real-time position feedback, and robust load-bearing structures to withstand dynamic pressures and cyclic fatigue over the aircraft’s operational lifespan.

details.description: Extend/retract flaps symmetrically or asymmetrically to adjust wing camber and surface area for lift augmentation or drag generation.
Synchronize flap deployment with slat systems to maintain aerodynamic balance during configuration changes.
Achieve full flap extension from 0° to 40° within 3 seconds under maximum aerodynamic load.
Maintain angular positioning accuracy within ±0.5° during deployment to prevent asymmetric lift conditions.
Implement dual-channel hydraulic/electric actuators with cross-monitoring to prevent single-point failures.
Enable mechanical locking in current position upon loss of hydraulic pressure or electrical power.
Design flap tracks and carriage mechanisms for ≥100,000 deployment cycles without structural degradation.
Provide quick-disconnect fittings and alignment guides for rapid flap replacement during line maintenance.

systemComponents.name: Flap Assembly
systemComponents.description: Primary deployable surface assembly comprising segmented panels, tracks, and supports.

subComponents.name: Flap Panel
subComponents.description: Aerodynamically shaped composite structure that extends rearward to increase wing area and camber.

subComponents.name: Track System
subComponents.description: Guided rails with roller bearings enabling smooth flap translation during extension/retraction.

systemComponents.name: Actuation Mechanism
systemComponents.description: Power transmission system converting hydraulic/electric energy into linear/rotary motion for flap deployment.

subComponents.name: Power Drive Unit (PDU)
subComponents.description: Dual-redundant motor or hydraulic pump providing torque for flap movement.

subComponents.name: Torque Tube
subComponents.description: Shaft transmitting rotational force from PDU to flap track screw jacks.

systemComponents.name: Flap Control Electronics
systemComponents.description: Control module processing commands from Flight Control Computer (FCC) and monitoring flap position.

subComponents.name: Flap Control Module
subComponents.description: Computes deployment angles based on airspeed, altitude, and pilot input.

subComponents.name: Position Feedback Sensors
subComponents.description: Resolvers or LVDTs providing real-time flap angle data to flight control systems.

relationships.description: The Flap System is aggregated under the Flight Surfaces as a dedicated control surface subsystem for lift/drag management.
Flap deployment commands are received from the Actuator Control Module via ARINC 429 databus for execution.
The Control Electronics directly commands and monitors the Actuation Mechanism's Power Drive Unit (PDU).
Mechanical force from the Actuation Mechanism is transferred to the Flap Assembly via torque tubes and screw jacks.

attributes.name: maxDeflectionAngle
attributes.description: Maximum angular deployment limit of flaps for high-lift configurations.

attributes.name: deploymentLoadCapacity
attributes.description: Mechanical load-bearing capacity during full extension under dynamic pressure.

attributes.name: positionFeedbackLatency
attributes.description: End-to-end latency from sensor measurement to control loop update.

attributes.name: operationalTemperature
attributes.description: Qualified temperature range for reliable flap operation in all flight regimes.
